III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 09/03/2024, Youth A and Youth B ran away from the facility
due to multiple employees hitting them. On 09/04/2024, the
children ran away again. Supervisor 1 struck Youth A in the
morning resulting in him sustaining a quarter sized red, black and
blue mark on his shoulder. Supervisor 1 has hit Youth B in the
past but not for the last week. One week ago, Supervisor 1
caused Youth B to sustain a scratch and a bruise on his upper left
arm. The children will speak or ask a question and staff will
threaten to take them into the blind spots of the cameras and fight
them.
Investigation Case Manager was interviewed via phone on 9/5/2024. She
reported Youth A is a “special youth” because Youth A is
aggressive towards staff and peers. Youth A uses racial slurs
towards others and has tried to stab staff and peers. Case
Manager reported Youth A is attempting to sabotage Youth A’s
current placement. Case Manager has never witnessed any
aggression from staff towards Youth A and she visits with Youth A
once a week. She reported never witnessing staff raise their
voices towards Youth A. Youth A is reported to go AWOL almost
daily and will steal items or panhandle when gone. Case Manager
reported Youth A informed her that Supervisor 1 is abusive
towards Youth A and claimed Supervisor 1 bruised Youth A’s right
kneecap, pinched Youth A’s neck in a blind spot in the hallway
when Youth A was going AWOL and placed Youth A in a choke
hold. Youth A informed her that Youth A is fearful at nighttime
because this is when Supervisor 1 works, and Supervisor 1 will
send peers into Youth A’s room to beat Youth A up.
Youth A was interviewed via phone on 9/5/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A reported being hit
2

by Supervisor 1 yesterday and having Supervisor 1 tell Youth E to
strike Youth A a few days ago. Youth A reported being hurt by
Supervisor 1 a few times but was unable to recall the specific
details of these incidents. Youth A reported Supervisor 1 hit Youth
A on the shoulder but was never given medical treatment for
Youth A’s injury. Supervisor 1 will use the blind spots on the floor
to hurt Youth A or send other youth to hurt Youth A. Youth A
reported witnessing Supervisor 1 hit Youth B which occurred a
week ago. Youth A reported never being hit by other staff nor
witnessing other staff strike a youth. Youth A admitted to going
AWOL often and having others (unidentified) while AWOL give
him money or different items including a bus token. When going
AWOL when Supervisor 1 is working, Supervisor 1 will tell Youth
A not to return to the facility.
Youth B was interviewed via phone on 9/5/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B reported not feeling
safe at the facility because Supervisor 1 has threatened Youth B.
No one else witnessed the threatening by Supervisor 1 except
Youth A who Youth B witnessed being hit by Supervisor 1. The
reason no one else witnessed Supervisor 1 hit Youth B is because
Supervisor 1 will hit Youth B in the blind spots on the floor. Youth
B reported Supervisor 1 is violent because Supervisor 1 pushed
Youth B while in the bedroom, but no one witnessed this incident.
Youth B has never witnessed any other staff threaten or abuse
any other youth with the exception of Supervisor 1 hitting Youth A
a couple of weeks ago. Youth B reported Youth A was swinging at
Supervisor 1 when Supervisor 1 hit Youth A in the chest. Youth B
denied witnessing other youth hit Youth A. Youth B reported
Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 have told Youth B and Youth A not
to come back when going AWOL. Youth B reported other youth
heard this but was unable to identify who these youth were.
Youth C was interviewed via phone on 9/5/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C denied witnessing
any staff hit or being inappropriate with any youth at the facility.
Youth C reported being on the same floor as Youth A and that
Supervisor 1 has never been inappropriate with Youth A. Youth C
denied staff take youth to the blind spot on the floor. Youth C also
reported staff will walk with youth going AWOL and try to get the
youth to stay at the facility. Staff will say “don’t do this and don’t
leave”. Youth C feels safe at the facility and only goes AWOL to
smoke and walk to Youth C’s home which is close by.
Youth D was interviewed via phone on 9/5/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth D reported being
3

lodged on the same floor of the facility as Youth B and has not
witnessed any abuse or threats by staff towards youth. Youth D
reported no staff are telling youth to beat up other youth. Youth D
reported witnessing Youth A spit on staff but was unable to recall
who the staff was. Youth D denied staff take youth to any blind
spots on the floor. In regard to youth going AWOL, Youth D
reported staff encourage youth to stay at the facility and Youth D
has never heard staff tell a youth to not come back.
Administrator was interviewed via phone on 9/5/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported Supervisor 1 is
a supervisor at the facility and will also work on the floor when a
need for additional staff occurs. She reported Supervisor 1 works
primarily second shift. Administrator reported Youth A has been
spitting on staff and other youth’s faces and going AWOL almost
daily. Youth A has refused to receive medical care following an
AWOL (standard practice) or when suffering an injury from other
youth during a fight. Youth A is on one-on-one supervision and
never without direct staff supervision.
Administrator was interviewed again face-to-face at the
facility on 9/6/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Administrator reported Supervisor 1 does not work first shift
therefore Supervisor 1 could not have hit Youth A in the morning
on 9/3/24 as outlined in the allegations. The incident report for the
allegations occurring on 9/3/24 documents Youth A and Youth B
left the building at 11:30 am and Supervisor 1 was not present at
work at that time. Administrator reported on 9/4/24 Supervisor 1
was not working at the facility. Administrator also reported youth
understand that Administrator is proactive and if informed of some
inappropriate behavior by staff, Administrator will investigate and
review video recordings. In February, Youth B informed
Administrator of an incident with staff and after reviewing the video
recordings, a staff was fired for pushing Youth B. Administrator
reported Youth A was bit by another youth which was the cause of
the bruising on Youth A’s shoulder and Youth B came back from
AWOLing on 8/31/24 with an injury on Youth B’s left arm.
Administrator will send a dated picture of Youth B’s arm. In regard
to the allegation of Supervisor 1 hitting Youth B and causing the
injury to Youth B’s arm Supervisor 1 was not working at the facility
on 9/4/24.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/6/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Supervisor 2
reported working with Supervisor 1 during second shift at the
facility. Supervisor 2 reported being surprised about the
4

allegations and he has never been informed by staff or youth
about staff assaulting youth. Supervisor 2 reported Supervisor 1
normally works the third floor and is not around Youth B.
Supervisor 2 has never witnessed any assaults against either
Youth A nor Youth B. Supervisor 2 reported staff avoid going into
the blind spots and the bedrooms in those areas are only used
when the census is high. He reported a person would still be
caught on camera going into those spots. He denied hearing
anything about or seeing staff encourage youth to jump other
youth. He reported if hearing something like that or becoming
aware of something like that, he would contract Administrator,
investigate, and complete an incident report. He reported that he
would take the same action if hearing a staff told a youth not to
return when going AWOL, because “they don’t need staff like that
at the facility”. In regard to medical attention, Supervisor 2
reported youth are to be taken for medical care if injured and
when returning from AWOL. There is a form that is completed and
if the youth refuses staff use a second form for refusing medical
treatment. Youth are asked to sign this second form and if
refusing, a second staff (present when processing the situation)
will sign the form as a witness.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
9/6/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He denied
working 9/3 nor 9/4 and reported his normal off days are Tuesday
and Wednesday of each week. He reported working second shift
(3:00 pm to 10:00 pm). Supervisor 1 denied ever hitting Youth A
or Youth B. He reported both youth come back from their AWOLs
with bruising and staff take pictures of the marks and bruising they
incurred while AWOL. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A engages in a
lot of fighting with staff and peers causing some bruising. Youth A
becomes dysregulated when told Youth A can’t do something or
being told no. When confronted by staff for Youth A’s behaviors,
Youth A will scream “rape” and become very assaultive. He
reported the only incident he had with Youth B was a restraint
(witnessed by other staff) that took place in front of the facility
building. Supervisor 1 denied telling other youth to beat up Youth
A or Youth B and denied taking any youth into the blind spot on
the floor. He reported if going into a youth’s bedroom, a second
staff will be present to serve as a witness. Supervisor 1 gave the
same report about medical treatment refusal as Supervisor 2
provided. Supervisor 1 denied ever hearing any staff tell a youth
not to return to the facility when going AWOL.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 9/16/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported working with
5

Supervisor 1 when Staff 1 works a double. He reported having no
issues with Supervisor 1 and never witnessing any of the
allegations. Staff 1 described Supervisor 1 as one of the best
supervisors at the facility. He reported never being informed by
any youth that Supervisor 1 engaged in inappropriate behaviors.
He reported never hearing Supervisor 1 tell other youth to hit
Youth A or Youth B. Staff 1 reported the AWOL process as
explained by others and is written in the AWOL policy. Staff 1
reported never hearing a staff tell youth not to return from going
AWOL. Staff 1 described Youth A as getting upset when not
getting his way and using racial remarks while trying to hit staff or
other youth. Youth A spits on youth and staff and becomes very
aggressive both verbally and physically.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 9/16/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported working
mostly on first shift but working with Supervisor 1 when working a
double shift. She denied ever witnessing any behaviors from
Supervisor 1 that matched the allegations and has never observed
Supervisor 1 engage in inappropriate behaviors. She described
Supervisor 1 as being very encouraging with the youth. Staff 2
reported working as the one-on-one staff for Youth A but because
of Youth A’s level of aggression, female staff are not given the
assignment of one-on-one supervision of Youth A. Youth A will
use verbal and physical aggression with youth and staff and will
spit on youth and staff. Staff 1 reported Youth B will go AWOL and
not take his medication. Youth B will go AWOL with Youth A and
not return until late into the night. She gave the same report as
other about staff’s responsibility when youth go AWOL.
Youth E was interviewed via phone on 9/18/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth E reported
remembering his fight with Youth A when Youth E bit Youth A.
Youth E was unable to remember where Youth E bit Youth A.
Youth E reported being mad at Youth A because Youth A called
Youth E a “cracker”. Youth E reported being afraid of Youth A, but
that staff will keep Youth E safe from Youth A.
Video Reviews:
There was no video recording of interactions between Youth A
and Supervisor 1 with the exception of an interaction that occurred
on 8/29/24. This recording was on the north hallway on the third
floor for the facility and showed Youth A’s bedroom door. The
recording occurred at 7:12 pm and began when Youth A and
Supervisor 1 entered the hallway from the stairway. Supervisor 1
followed Youth A to Youth A’s bedroom and Youth A went into the
6

bedroom. Supervisor 1 is providing the 1:1 supervision for Youth A
and stands in the hallway, checking on Youth A who is still in the
bedroom on a regular basis. The video ends when Supervisor 1 is
relieved by another staff who provides supervision during sleeping
hours which is reported to not be 1:1 at that time. There is no
video of any interactions between Youth B and Supervisor 1.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services Residential Services Truancy
Policy and Procedure Policy dated 3/14/24. This document
outlines the “Truancy Prevention Procedure” that staff are to
follow. Staff are to make efforts to verbally redirect the youth, offer
support, and alternatives to going truant. If a non-supervising staff
is available, this staff should walk along with the youth and provide
verbal support and redirection. Staff are not to physically intervene
with youth. Staff are to complete an incident report. It is
documented that when the youth returns to the facility the
appropriate supervising agency must be contacted.
Wolverine Human Services Residential Services Policy for
CPI in Residential Programs Behavior Support and
Management dated 2024. This document outlines that all staff
are to be certified in Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI), Non-Violent
Crisis Intervention. Staff are to provide immediate emotional and
environmental support to youth in crisis and to teach youth more
constructive effective ways of dealing with stress. It is documented
in this policy that staff are never to engage in the use of non-
violent physical restrictions as a form of punishment or discipline.
Youth A and Youth B incident reports at the time of the
allegations:
Wolverine Human Services Critical Incident Report dated
9/3/24 @ 11:11 am AWOL for Youth A. It is documented that
staff present tried to redirect while speaking with Youth A in an
attempt to have Youth A not AWOL. Youth A is documented as
not listening and walked off the property because he wanted to go
to Walmart. It is documented that Youth A had no visible marks,
bruises, nor injuries on his body. There is no documentation of
Supervisor 1 being present at the time.
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Notification Report
dated 9/4/24 @ 2:52 am Return from AWOL for Youth A.
Documentation indicates Youth A was “dropped off” at the facility
by Law Enforcement. Youth A is documented as being very dirty
and without underwear. Youth A refused to get a medical
7

clearance, but staff did not observe any marks, scars, or bruises.
Youth A took a shower, was provided clean clothing, and went to
bed. There is no documentation of Supervisor 1 being present at
the time.
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Notification Report
dated 9/4/24 @ 8:45 am bite mark on Youth A. It is documented
that Youth was attacked by Youth E and Youth E bit Youth A on
the upper right shoulder. Documentation indicates several staff
intervened to separate the two youth. Youth A is documented as
refusing medical clearance and staff were able to apply ointment
to the wound. There is no documentation of Supervisor 1 being
present at the time.
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Notification Report
dated 9/4/24 @ 8:45 am for Youth E. It is documented that Youth
E became aggressive and attacked Youth A outside of the facility.
Staff had to intervene and removed Youth E away from Youth A.
Youth A punched Youth E in the nose causing Youth E to have a
bloody nose which required medical treatment. There is no
documentation of Supervisor 1 being present at the time.
Wolverine Human Services Critical Incident Report dated
9/4/24@ 9:30 am AWOL for Youth A. It is documented that
Youth A became dysregulated and began to violently attack other
youth and staff before leaving the facility. Staff keep other youth
safe from Youth A’s assaults and it is documented that Youth A
had struck staff at the time. Youth A is documented as being in
“high speed” when leaving so the body check was not able to be
completed. There is no documentation of Supervisor 1 being
present at the time.
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Notification Report
dated 9/5/24 @ 2:44 am Return from AWOL for Youth A.
Documentation indicates Youth A was “dropped off” at the facility
by Law Enforcement. Youth had contraband (unidentified) and
staff observed a bite mark on his upper right shoulder. Youth A is
documented as not knowing where or when Youth A received the
bite mark. Youth A refused medical clearance and went to bed.
The medical clearance form had a second staff witness Youth A’s
refusal to sign. There is no documentation of Supervisor 1 being
present at the time.
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Notification Report
dated 9/3/24 @ 11:00 am AWOL for Youth B. It is documented
Youth A left with Youth B after retrieving something from Youth
8

B’s room. Staff asked for the item, but Youth B refused and left the
facility with Youth A. Staff is documented as trying to redirect both
youth to avoid going AWOL, but they refused. Youth B was
documented as having no marks, bruising, or injuries. There is no
documentation of Supervisor 1 being present at the time.
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Notification Report
dated 9/4/24 @ 2:53 am Return from AWOL for Youth B.
Documentation indicates Youth B was “dropped off” at the facility
by Law Enforcement. Youth B is documented as having no marks,
scars, or bruises upon returning to the facility. Youth B refused
medical clearance. There is no documentation of Supervisor 1
being present at the time.
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Notification Report
dated 9/4/24 @ 10:40 am AWOL for Youth B. It is documented
that Youth B refused redirection and staff’s efforts to convince
Youth B to stay at the facility. Youth B is documented as saying
Youth A is his “source” and Youth B needs to go AWOL with
Youth A. Documentation indicates Youth B has no marks,
bruising, nor injuries at the time of leaving the facility. There is no
documentation of Supervisor 1 being present at the time.
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Notification Report
dated 9/5/24 @ 2:44 am Return from AWOL for Youth B.
Documentation indicates Youth A was “dropped off” at the facility
by Law Enforcement. Youth B had no marks, scars, or bruising
and refused medical clearance. There is no documentation of
Supervisor 1 being present at the time.
Wolverine Center Shelter Program Statement dated 9/12/24.
This statement provides temporary shelter, placement planning,
crisis intervention, and short-term treatment to youth males. This
program serves males aged 10-17 and staff ratio is 1:2 during
waking hours and 1:4 during sleeping hours..
Wolverine Center St. Judes: Mental Health and Behavior
Stabilization dated 9/12/24. This document outlines the program
statement as a CBT-based skills and strategies program for youth
males. The staffing ratio during awake hours is 1:2 and 1:4 during
sleeping hours. Males aged 12 through 17 who are experiencing
moderate to severe DSM-5 mental health disorders are eligible for
admission. Other issues served at the facility include co-occurring
substance use disorders, trauma-based issues and related
behavioral problems. Several different forms of therapy are officed
including Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, motivational Interviewing,
9

and psychiatric services to name a few. Education services are
offered, and life skills are taught.
Supervisor 1’s personnel file: Documentation indicates
Supervisor 1 was hired on 7/8/2024 and there is no disciplinary
action documents in the file. Staff 1 is current on his training.
Time Resources Timesheet dated 8/25 through 9/4/24 for
Supervisor 1. This document shows Supervisor did not work
beyond 12:00 PM to 1:30 PM on 9/3/24 (attending a staffing
meeting at that time) and did not work at all on 9/4/24.
Email from Administrator on 10/7/24. Administrator reports
Supervisor 1 attended the staffing meeting on 9/3/24 from 12:00
PM to 1:30 PM.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance based on interviews, video
review and documentation reviewed, Supervisor 1 wasn’t working
at the facility during the times outlined in the allegations and no
other individual (staff and youth) interviewed supported the
allegations besides Youth A and Youth B.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: An investigation was conducted into allegations that a supervisor at a youth facility struck two residents, caused injuries, and used threats and blind spots to avoid detection. The investigation included interviews with multiple youths, staff, and administrators, as well as reviews of video footage and incident reports. The investigation found that the accused supervisor was not working at the times of the alleged incidents, no other witnesses corroborated the claims, and the documented injuries were attributed to other causes like fights between youth. Based on the evidence, the allegations were not substantiated, and the facility was found in compliance; therefore, the accused supervisor is not deemed culpable based on this report's findings.
